Chamomite.-A medical correspondent at Mads
rid, has acquainted friend in ireland with some
Astonishing effects OF the herb chamumi's in certain
inAammalory disorders Of he eye, when every other
remedy usually prescribed, had proved aboitne.
Fhe following, among many wherein the
doctor has been concerned Is mentioned A. proof
Of the virtues of this salutary though common herb
Maria de Maros, daughter of a MASTER carpenter,
had for many years been sfflicted with weeping
eyes, which discharged an acrimonious fluid that
brought on an almo, total loss Of sight Alternatives
were prescribed TO no purpose, nor could q course
OF mercury procure the smallest aneviation. At
length he msde.a strong decoctiun of chan omile,
boiled in sweet cows milk +; with this the patient
bathed her eyes several times a day, as warm as
could be suffered without unea.iness; and in abous
Ave weeks, her eyes were perfectly cured.


Boston Medical Lteligencer.

Sec. 7. .1ad be 1t enacted, That it shall be the
duty OF the Judge OF any infeiior Court OF Common
Pleas OF this state. when he grants or issues any
certificate or warrant of removal Of any negro or
mualto, claimed to be fugitive from labor to the
state or territory from which he she fed, in pur-
suance Of an act of Congress, passed on the 18th
day OF February one thousand seven hundred and
ninety three, entitled AN act respecting fugitiyes
from justice and persons escaping from the service Of
their masters" )" and of this act to make fair re-
cord OF the same, in which he shall enter the names
age, sex. aud general description Of the person Of
the negro or mulalo, for whom he shall grant such
&C ticate warrant of removal, together with the
evidence and the of places OF residence of the
and Drfv rIaIfp rh
mula,o and shall wi.hio ten days thereafter, file
certified copy thereof in the Office Of the clerk Of
the inferior Court oi Common Pleas OF the county
in which he may reside.


Sec. g. find be 1t enacted That if any person or
persons shall seize arrest or take any person upder
pretence that such person is held to labor or service
in any other OF the United States, in either of
the territories thereof and hath escaped into thia
state without having previously 90 aimed the
herein before mentioned, or without having other
legal authority tor the purpose under some act OF
the legislature OF this state OF the Congress Of
the Unied States; or il any two or more persons
beine armed, shall assemble together and enter the
dwelling house or place OF .bode Of any oher per-
son, under pretenec Of searching or any person or
pc sons held 10 service in any other oil the
United States, either ot tht territories thereof,
and who hath or have escaped into th, state with
out havlrg previously obtained the warrant herein
before mentioned or without having other legal .u-
thorlty for the purpose under some act Of the lees.
latue of his state of the Congress of the United

or taking as afore aid, and such persons assem-
bling as aforesaid, and entering aforesaid. shall
be deemed guilty Of misdeme anor and on convIc-
ton thereof, shall be punished by 6ne not exceeding
one thousand dollars, or by Imprisonment At hard
labor, not exceeding two years, both, the dis
CT elton of the court before whom such conviction
may be had

WILMINGTON, Del TUESDAY, FEBRUARY g. 1927
Volume vi.

TO the Memory Of my Mfant Niece, E. B.


rob Feb. 6. 1826-lEt. 81
For ever gone f--sweet bud OF spring!


Yes; from its paren, stem 'tis riven!
Scarce had it drank the morning dew,
Or oped its petals to our view,
Ere destin'd twas, asi 2 20 fling


II, earthly form, aud bloom in Heaven!
'Yes, thou art gone!--nor pray'rs nor sghs
Can anght a,ail!-'twas Death who sought thee
Those cherub smiles, that lisping tongue.
Those arms which round thy mother cung,
Had marked thee for he tyrant's prize


And in hs cold embrace he's caught thee!
slow oft, when lulling thee to sleep.


I've seen thy mother fondy press thee,
How often kiss away thy tears,
A d hush thy cries. and calm thy fears
Aud when thou still wouldst sob and weep,
With what affection She caress thee
'For as she watch'd thy opening bloom,


Predicting future days of pleasure,
She lit k thought misforune's blight,
So soon would wither her delight -
She dream not tha, early tomb


Would close upon her infant treasure
'Great were her hapes!-yet doubtless, fears
With all hei cheering hopes were blended;
For, hapy none like parents feel
The hopes and fears hey'd fain conceal
Increasing with increasing wears,


Till lite aud all its cares are ended.
Yet, who could vie thy dmpled cheek,
And look for aught bat years Of gladnesss
Or see thy laughing dark blue eye,
Aud think that sorrow so nigh -
Or hear thee frs essay to speak,


And then iolebode this scene of sadness
Ba, sh! our prospects-oh, how vain!


Our ANXIOUS cares-,h, how requitedl
muther's iive-a fahei's PRIDE
How near to misery allied
Their JOY, how soon exchanged for pain!
Their every hope, how quickly blghed!
'And is it weakness, then, to mourn,


When thus our dearest hopes are thwarted!
When in the arms of icy Death
A spotess babe resigns its breath!
To see il from its kindred torn!


A mother from her infant parted,
sOh, no!-it weakness ne'er can be,


When woe-begone, to show our feeling!
To shed the sympathetic tear
In mournful silence DER the bier
OF one so lOvd in infancy


Such grief, alas, there's no cencealing!
But since the fatal die is cast,


And unavailing, now, is sorrow,--
o grant, kind Heav'n that future Joy
And bliss serene, withnu, alloy,
Exchanged may be for troubles past,


And skies unclouded gid the morrow
.jt9-9rn

TO the Memory ofmy Infant Niece, E. B.

Thus far we have had very little cold weather.
all put together would NOT make more than two
weeks Of cold. We have had black Iros, but one
morning, very little rain throughout the fall. This
day more rein has fallen than on any day this fall.
Our peach trees mostly in blossom, and our Sc
cond crop Of apples arc as large as plums.

Chamomite.-A medical correspondent at Mads
rid, has acquainted friend in ireland with some
Astonishing effects OF the herb chamumi's in certain
inAammalory disorders Of he eye, when every other
remedy usually prescribed, had proved aboitne.
Fhe following, among many wherein the
doctor has been concerned Is mentioned A. proof
Of the virtues of this salutary though common herb
Maria de Maros, daughter of a MASTER carpenter,
had for many years been sfflicted with weeping
eyes, which discharged an acrimonious fluid that
brought on an almo, total loss Of sight Alternatives
were prescribed TO no purpose, nor could q course
OF mercury procure the smallest aneviation. At
length he msde.a strong decoctiun of chan omile,
boiled in sweet cows milk +; with this the patient
bathed her eyes several times a day, as warm as
could be suffered without unea.iness; and in abous
Ave weeks, her eyes were perfectly cured.


Boston Medical Lteligencer.

Sec 6. find be 1t enacted, That the officers
which may or shall be employed in tine execution

dately on the performance Of the duties aforesaid.


Sec. 7. .1ad be 1t enacted, That it shall be the
duty OF the Judge OF any infeiior Court OF Common
Pleas OF this state. when he grants or issues any
certificate or warrant of removal Of any negro or
mualto, claimed to be fugitive from labor to the
state or territory from which he she fed, in pur-
suance Of an act of Congress, passed on the 18th
day OF February one thousand seven hundred and
ninety three, entitled AN act respecting fugitiyes
from justice and persons escaping from the service Of
their masters" )" and of this act to make fair re-
cord OF the same, in which he shall enter the names
age, sex. aud general description Of the person Of
the negro or mulalo, for whom he shall grant such
&C ticate warrant of removal, together with the
evidence and the of places OF residence of the
and Drfv rIaIfp rh
mula,o and shall wi.hio ten days thereafter, file
certified copy thereof in the Office Of the clerk Of
the inferior Court oi Common Pleas OF the county
in which he may reside.


Sec. g. find be 1t enacted That if any person or
persons shall seize arrest or take any person upder
pretence that such person is held to labor or service
in any other OF the United States, in either of
the territories thereof and hath escaped into thia
state without having previously 90 aimed the
herein before mentioned, or without having other
legal authority tor the purpose under some act OF
the legislature OF this state OF the Congress Of
the Unied States; or il any two or more persons
beine armed, shall assemble together and enter the
dwelling house or place OF .bode Of any oher per-
son, under pretenec Of searching or any person or
pc sons held 10 service in any other oil the
United States, either ot tht territories thereof,
and who hath or have escaped into th, state with
out havlrg previously obtained the warrant herein
before mentioned or without having other legal .u-
thorlty for the purpose under some act Of the lees.
latue of his state of the Congress of the United
States such person or persons, 30 seEing. arrestng
or taking as afore aid, and such persons assem-
bling as aforesaid, and entering aforesaid. shall
be deemed guilty Of misdeme anor and on convIc-
ton thereof, shall be punished by 6ne not exceeding
one thousand dollars, or by Imprisonment At hard
labor, not exceeding two years, both, the dis
CT elton of the court before whom such conviction
may be had


Sec. 9 and be it enacted That the seventh sec.
ton Of" " An act respecting SIav.s" passed the fosr.
een.h day of March, seventeen hundred and
ninety eight and all other or parts of acts COM
ing within the purvlew OF this act, be and the same
are hereby repealed.


c. Passed Dec 27, 1896.

full articles.headline:
The following beautiful stanzas are from Deaths d
i,gs," ork Of great merit.


TO the Memory ofmy Infant Niece, E. B.
full articles.article:
TO the Memory Of my Mfant Niece, E. B.


rob Feb. 6. 1826-lEt. 81
For ever gone f--sweet bud OF spring!


Yes; from its paren, stem 'tis riven!
Scarce had it drank the morning dew,
Or oped its petals to our view,
Ere destin'd twas, asi 2 20 fling


II, earthly form, aud bloom in Heaven!
'Yes, thou art gone!--nor pray'rs nor sghs
Can anght a,ail!-'twas Death who sought thee
Those cherub smiles, that lisping tongue.
Those arms which round thy mother cung,
Had marked thee for he tyrant's prize


And in hs cold embrace he's caught thee!
slow oft, when lulling thee to sleep.


I've seen thy mother fondy press thee,
How often kiss away thy tears,
A d hush thy cries. and calm thy fears
Aud when thou still wouldst sob and weep,
With what affection She caress thee
'For as she watch'd thy opening bloom,


Predicting future days of pleasure,
She lit k thought misforune's blight,
So soon would wither her delight -
She dream not tha, early tomb


Would close upon her infant treasure
'Great were her hapes!-yet doubtless, fears
With all hei cheering hopes were blended;
For, hapy none like parents feel
The hopes and fears hey'd fain conceal
Increasing with increasing wears,


Till lite aud all its cares are ended.
Yet, who could vie thy dmpled cheek,
And look for aught bat years Of gladnesss
Or see thy laughing dark blue eye,
Aud think that sorrow so nigh -
Or hear thee frs essay to speak,


And then iolebode this scene of sadness
Ba, sh! our prospects-oh, how vain!


Our ANXIOUS cares-,h, how requitedl
muther's iive-a fahei's PRIDE
How near to misery allied
Their JOY, how soon exchanged for pain!
Their every hope, how quickly blghed!
'And is it weakness, then, to mourn,


When thus our dearest hopes are thwarted!
When in the arms of icy Death
A spotess babe resigns its breath!
To see il from its kindred torn!


A mother from her infant parted,
sOh, no!-it weakness ne'er can be,


When woe-begone, to show our feeling!
To shed the sympathetic tear
In mournful silence DER the bier
OF one so lOvd in infancy


Such grief, alas, there's no cencealing!
But since the fatal die is cast,


And unavailing, now, is sorrow,--
o grant, kind Heav'n that future Joy
And bliss serene, withnu, alloy,
Exchanged may be for troubles past,


And skies unclouded gid the morrow

Thus far we have had very little cold weather.
all put together would NOT make more than two
weeks Of cold. We have had black Iros, but one
morning, very little rain throughout the fall. This
day more rein has fallen than on any day this fall.
Our peach trees mostly in blossom, and our Sc
cond crop Of apples arc as large as plums.

And that any sheriff or constable receiving and ex

Sec. 4. find be ii enacted, That the said fugitive

Sec. g. find be it enacted. That when the fugitive

county, or in term time ut the chamber Of the said
